summary.seg: This Greek manuscript contains two comedies, Plutus (known also as Wealth), Clouds, by the Athenian writer Aristophanes (c. 446-385 BCE), along with the scholia by the Byzantine grammarians Thomas Magistros and Demetrius Triclinius (13th-14th century).

Many of the leaves have been mended, in all likelihood in the 18th century. Unfortunately the letters closest to the gutter are not fully readable because they are covered with stubs or because the binding does not allow the manuscript to be opened fully.
The manuscript is cited in Aristophanes' editions as Cant. 3 or Ct3, and it was collated by P. Dobree ( Ricardi Porsoni notae in Aristophanem, Cambridge 1820).

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Thoman Life of Aristophanes (Vita XXXIII 1 ed. Koster 1975, Scholia in Aristophanem I.1.a)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Ἀριστοφάνης ὁ κωμωδοποιὸς γένει μὲν ἦν Ἀθηναῖος· Πανδιονίδος φιλῆς· πάνυ δὲ ὢν εὐφυὴς καὶ ἀγχίνους ἐν νέα κωμιδῆ τῇ ἡλικίᾳ εὐδοκίμησεν ἐν κωμωδίαις
msItem.explicit: f. 1r ἀποθανόντα δὲ οὕτω πλάτων· ἐτίμησεν ἡρωελεγείῳ· ἐπίγραμμα πλάτωνος εἰς τὸν τάφον ἀριστοφάνους αἱ Χάριτες τέμενος ὅπερ οὐχὶ πεσεῖται, ζητοῦσαι ψυχὴν εὗρον ἀριστοφάνους
msItem.note: From ἐπίγραμμα to ἀριστοφάνους in red ink. About the epigram, cf. Greek Anthology Appendix III 33 and DBBE type 5362

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on Plutus
Thoman Argumentum (ed. Chantry 1996, Scholia in Aristophanem III.4.b)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r βουλόμενος ἀριστοφάνης σκῶψαι ἀθηναίους ἀδικία καὶ συκοφαντία καὶ τοῖς τοιούτοις συνόντας
msItem.explicit: f. 1v οὐκ αὐτοὶ μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ ὅσοι βίου χρηστοῦ πρόσθεν ἀντεχόμενοι πένητες ἦσαν

msItem.title: On the comedy
De Comoedia (cf. Vita Thomana XXXIII 2 ed. Koster 1975, Scholia in Aristophanem I.1.a)
msItem.incipit: f. 1v Κωμωδία ἐκλήθη· ἀπὸ τοῦ ἐν κώμαις ἄδεσθαι κώμας γὰρ ἐκάλουν οἱ παλαιοὶ τοὺς στενωποὺς
msItem.note: followed by the list of characters of the Plutus

msItem.title: Scholion 1b to Plutus (ed. Chantry 1996, Scholia in Aristophanem III.4.b)
msItem.incipit: f. 1v ὁρῶν ὁ καρίων τὸν ἑαυτοῦ δεσπότην χρεμύλον μετὰ τὸ ἐξελθεῖν τοῦ μαντείου τυφλῷ ἀνδρὶ ἑπόμενον σχετλιάζων καὶ δυσφορῶν λέγει τοῦτο
msItem.note: added by a later hand. ὁρῶν ὁ καρίων τὸν ἑαυτοῦ δεσπότην χρεμύλον repeated on lower margin

msItem.author: Aristophanes
msItem.title: Plutus
Wealth
msItem.rubric: f. 2r ἀριστοφάνους πλοῦτος προλογίζει ὁ καρίων
msItem.incipit: f. 2r ὡς ἀργαλέον πρᾶγμ’ ἐστίν ὦ Ζεῦ καὶ θεοί, δοῦλον γενέσθαι παραφρονοῦντος δεσπότου
msItem.explicit: f. 39r οὐκ ἔτι τοίνυν γ’ εἰκὸς μέλλειν οὐδ’ ἡμᾶς ἀλλ’ ἀναχωρεῖν εἰς τοὔπισθεν· δεῖ γὰρ κατόπιν τούτοις ἄδοντας ἕπεσθαι
msItem.note: extensive scholia and interlinear glosses accompany the text

some folios are misplaced but the foliation numbers run consistently with the text: ff. 12r-13v are misplaced after f. 15v, ff. 16r-17v after f. 18v. This arrangement pre-dates the current binding, and a reader has noted the correct reading order of the folios on the lower margin of f. 11v and f. 13v

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on Nubes
Thoman Argumentum Nubium (Arg. Ia ed. Koster 1974, Scholia in Aristophanem I.3.2)
msItem.incipit: f. 39v Ἄνυτος καὶ Μέλητος Σωκράτει τῶ Σωφρονίσκου βασκήναντες, καὶ αὐτὸν μη δυνάμενοι βλάψαι, ἀργύριον ἱκανὸν Ἀριστοφάνει δεδώκασιν
msItem.explicit: f. 39v συνίσταται δὲ τὸ δράμα ἐκ χοροῦ Νεφελῶν· ἔχει δὲ κατηγορίαν τοῦ Σωκράτους· ὅτι τοὺς συνήθους θεοὺς ἀφεὶς καινὰ ἐνόμιζε δαιμόνια, ἀέρα, νεφέλας καὶ τὰ τοιαῦτα
msItem.note: followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Aristophanes
msItem.title: Nubes
Clouds
msItem.incipit: f. 40r ἰού ἰού ὦ ζεῦ βασιλεῦ τὸ χρῆμα τῶν νυκτῶν ὅσον ἀπέραντον. οὐδέποθ’ ἡμέρα γενήσεται
msItem.explicit: f. 83r ἡγεῖσθ’ ἔξω κεχόρευται γὰρ μετρίως τό γε τήμερον ἡμῖν
msItem.note: extensive scholia in brown ink and interlinear glosses accompany the text
ff. 48r-48v have been replaced by ff. 48*r-48*v without any loss of text

msItem.title: Owner's or reader's note
msItem.note: The same note is found on CUL, MS Ff.4.47, f. 23v. Cf. RGK I 359.

support.material: ff. 1r-83v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: upper part barely visible on ff. 43, 57, 60, 75, 76: Ascending with cross ( 35 30 ) near the gutter comparable to the type of Briquet, 5236, dated 1496.

supportDesc.foliation: [i-iii] + 1-11, 14, 15, 12, 13, 18, 16, 17, 19-47, 48*, 49-83 + [iv-vi]. Modern foliation in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto.

collation.p:
The manuscript originally consisted of ten quaternions and a final quire of three leaves. The original state of the quires was modified in the 18th century with extensive use of stubs, prior to the misplacing of ff. 14-18. The binding is too tight to determine the colation confidently:
Quire 18-1 ff. 1-7
Quire 24 ff. 8-11
Quire 32+2 ff. 14, 15, 12-13
Quire 43 ff. 18, 16, 17
Quire 512+2 ff. 19-30, 31, 32
Quire 68+8 ff. 33-40, 41-48*
Quires 7-108 ff. 49-80
Quire 113 ff. 81-83
Henry Bradshaw (1831-1886) added the bifolium signatures and a note on collation on f. [vi] recto, and notes throughout the manuscript on the lost and cancelled folios.

signatures.p: Quire signatures in Greek numerals from α to ια in red ink at the beginning and the end of quires, survive in the lower margin, probably original to the production of the manuscript. Some of them have been lost: α f. 8v; β ff. 9r and 16v ; Γ ff. 17r and 24v; δ ff. 25r and 32v; ε ff. 33r and 40v; ϛ f. 41r; ζ f. 49r (very faint); Η f. 57r (passed on f. 56v); θ and θον ff. 65r and 72v; ι f. 73r; ια f. 81r.

Later quire signatures in Greek numerals from α to ι in black ink usually at the beginning of quires, in the lower margin, and on lower margin of stubs (not visible on digital images), probably dating from the restoration of the manuscript in the 18th century: α f. 2r; β f. 8r; Γ ff. 14r and 13v (on stub); δ ff. 18r and 17v (on stub); ε ff. 19r and 32v (on stub); ϛ ff. 33r and 48*v (on stub); H f. 64v (on stub); θ f. 72v (on stub); ι f. 80v (on stub).

Bifolium signatures (Latin letters for quires, followed by Arabic numerals for bifolios) in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos of the first four folios, followed by a cross on the fifth, added by Henry Bradshaw: a-l.

supportDesc.condition: In fair condition. Some leaves are stained with moisture or ink (e.g. ff. 5r, 18r, 35v, 41v, 42v; f. 64r erased stain with loss of a few letters); there are several holes (e.g. f. 4), the edges are worn out. f. 6 partially detached, f. 39 upper inner corner and f. 66 lower margin corner cutted off.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-47v, 49r-83r: A single column of 16 lines. 190 100
Surrounding scholia that accompany the main texts have a very variable number of lines per page. The ruling for the main text and the scholia is traced and visible on all the folios.
ff. 48*r-48*v: A single column of 16-17 lines. 230 110

handNote.p: The texts and scholia are written in a mixed minuscule in an upright, scribal hand, in black ink script.

The writing is of reduced size and with large space for interlinear glosses. There is a moderate variation in letter size. Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are absent in the main text, rare in introductory materials and frequent in scholia. Breathings are curved and mute iota is not used non consistenly.

The general appearance of the writing appears rigid, since the core of the letters is inscribable in a square and the strokes are often built at right angles (e.g. ypsilon), however the descending strokes are traced with some softness.
The small majuscules beta, gamma, lambda and phi are present. Beta has a heart-shape, and epsilon is both regular minuscule and lunate. The sigma telikon is present along with regular shape.
Epsilon in ligature is deformed. Lambda in ligature with alpha or epsilon has an closed loop.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.
The integrated sheet is written a mixed miniscule similar to that of the main hand but more slanting to the right.
The name on f. 83v is written by the Greek monk Sabbas Sabbas from the Monastery of Dionysiou (RGK I 359).

decoDesc.decoNote: The Thoman Life of Aristophanes and Plutus are preceded by rectangular headpieces with vegetative ornament in red ink: ff. 1r and 2r. Blank space is left for a headpiece on f. 40r.
Minor initials in red ink, with simple ornament on ff. 1v, 39v and at the begin of each scholion.

additions.p:
f. 1r: a fragment of red wax seal on the lower margin, partly lost in trimming, with a small Greek cross and some letters of the legend still readable: + | ΑΝΤΟΝΙΟΥ | ΤΡΙΦΙΛΙ | 1713 , accompanied by the inscription απο του δεονισιου (sic) νουμερο 11. The same seal is preserved on CUL MS Nn.3.15, Part Ia f. 2r (with inscription: απο του δεονισιου (sic) νουμερο 8), and CUL MS Add. 2603, f. 459v; in the latter the legend + | ΑΝΤΟΝΙΟΥ | ΤΡΙΦΙΛΙ | 1713 is readable, accompanied by an inscription dated 18th July 1739, in the same hand as the inscription απο του δεονισιου on Nn.3.3, f. 1r. The same seal can be found on
Leiden, Bibliotheek der Rijksuniversiteit, BPG 74 G , f. 1*r, and traces of its impression can also be found on London, British Library, Add. MS 5153A , f. 5v.

The incipit of Plutus is copied by a later hand on the lower margin on f. 1r: + ὡς ἀργαλέον πρᾶγμ’ ἐστίν. It is partly written on paper used for the restoration of the manuscript and now almost entirely covered by the strip of paper that bears Triphilis' seal; only the accents and breathings are visible on digital images.
A sketch of a horse's head is drawn on f. 1v.
Henry Bradshaw added the bifolium signatures and a note on collation on f. [vi] recto, and notes throughout the manuscript on the lost and cancelled folios.

binding.p: Bound with pale brown full skin covering over millboards. There is decorative tooling on boards, spine and on the board edge. The title (Aristoph Plutus Nubes) is tooled in gold on the spine. Marbled paper is used as pastedowns with blank leaves.

history.origin: The palaeographic features and the watermark suggest that the manuscript was written in the late 15th century or early 16th century.

provenance.p: Nn.3.3 used to belong to the Monastery of Dionysiou on Mount Athos: on f. 1r in all likelihood Antonios Triphillis added απο του δεονισιου (sic) νουμερο 11, along with his seal (see above). The same hand of the note on f. 83v Σάββα Ἱερομόναχος wrote his name on CUL MS Ff.4.47, f. 23v alongside a note indicating it belonged to the Monastery (κτῆμα μονῆς τοῦ κυρίου Διονυσίου). Antonios Triphillis, who was an educated Greek of the diaspora, active in the first part of 18th century, may have been a dealer with access to Mt Athos monasteries or a collector, whose books were sold abroad. A similar inscription, by the same hand, can be found in CUL MS Add. 2603, f. 459v (νουμερο 7) and CUL MS Nn.3.15.1, f. 2r (νουμερο 8), which also have the seal impression. The manuscript belonged to the collection of the physician Richard Mead (1673-1754) Mead, Richard, 1673-1754 ; it later entered into the library of Anthony Askew (1722-1774) Askew, Anthony, 1722-1774 , physician and book collector.

history.acquisition: After Askew's death, his manuscripts were sold by G. Leigh and J. Sotheby in the auction of his library in 1785 (Nn.3.3 Lot. n. 556), and several, including Nn.3.3, were eventually bought by Richard Farmer for Cambridge University Library. The University of Cambridge general bookplate (engraved by William Jackson in 1706-1707) was added on the pastedown of left cover.

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 4, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1861, p. 474.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
